concept.title: System Components Description

othermeta.name: shortdesc
othermeta.content: Provides an overview of the main UPS system components, including rectifier, inverter, static bypass, battery modules, and control electronics, and explains how they function together.

othermeta.name: entities
othermeta.content: rectifier; inverter; static bypass; battery modules; control panel; power distribution board; communication interface; sensors

othermeta.name: usecase
othermeta.content: Help engineers, technicians, and operators understand the main UPS components and their functional relationships

sectiondiv.p: The image shows an example and a simplification of a system configuration with optional components intended as a reference for the description of the system components. See the Single Line Diagram for the configuration of your system.
sectiondiv.note: Optional parts are marked with a star.
sectiondiv.p:
The system components are divided into three sections:
(A) The connection field. Located in the bypass, distribution or incoming.
(B) The system part. Located in the system cabinet behind the main protection cover.
(C) The low voltage section. Located in the system cabinet in front of the main protection cover. The sections are divided to make maintenance and service easier. The connection field and system part physically isolated Not possible with integrated incoming section. from each other (different cabinets).

The system components are divided into two sections:
(A) The system part. Located in the system cabinet behind the main protection cover.
(B) The low voltage section. Located in the system cabinet in front of the main protection cover.
sectiondiv.note: The breakers in the diagram can be switch-disconnectors, fuse switch-disconnectors or circuit breakers.
The standard alphanumeric designations are shown and might be different on some systems.

entry.ph: Connection terminal for the bypass mains input. The bypass mains input requires an external protective device. A fuse or molded case circuit breaker (MCCB) according to the technical specification. L, N, PE for single phase systems. L1, L2, L3 and PE (and N if there is no isolation bypass transformer) for three phase systems. For specifications always refer to the Drawings for your system.
Breaker for the bypass mains input. The bypass mains input requires an external protective device. A fuse or MCCB according to the technical specification.
Galvanic isolation between bypass mains input and load. Used if the required output is different from the available input. Either a transformer or stabilizer can be used.
Makes it possible to isolate the system for maintenance and test the system without interruption. Positions are Auto, Test and Bypass. For more information see .
Makes it possible to isolate the system for maintenance. Positions are Auto and Bypass. For more information see .

Always used with 2-position manual bypass switches. Needed to isolates the static switch EN when the 2-position manual bypass switch is in Bypass position. This functionality is integrated in 3-position manual bypass switches.

Connection terminal for the rectifier mains DC power input. The rectifier mains DC power input requires an external protective device. A fuse or MCCB according to the technical specification. Always L1, L2, L3, and PE.
Rectifier input circuit breaker or switch-disconnector
Breaker for the rectifier mains input. The rectifier mains input requires an external protective device. A fuse or MCCB according to the technical specification.
Provides isolation for the DC power input. No trip function.
Connection terminal for the battery connection. The battery connection requires an external protective device. A fuse or MCCB according to the technical specification.

Breaker for the battery connection. Can be a battery protection device. If Q004 is not selected, Q005 has to be selected. It is possible to have both options.The battery connection, protection and breakers can also be part of the customers scope.

External battery protection device for the battery connection, must be installed according to the technical specification. If Q005 is not selected, Q004 has to be selected and Q004 must be a battery protection device. It is possible to have both options.
Connection terminal for the load. L, N, PE for single phase systems. L1, L2, L3, N and PE for three phase systems.
Galvanic isolation between mains input and rectifier. Transforms the mains input to the correct value for the rectifier.
Converts the AC voltage from the mains to DC voltage.

To create a 12-pulse thyristor rectifier-bridge an additional 6-pulse thyristor rectifier-bridge (with a 30 degree phase shift) can be used. This reduces the repercussion of the rectifier back to the mains.
Power fuse at the output of the thyristor rectifier-bridge.
Filters the DC current together with CB02.
Reduces the AC ripple to the battery generated by the single phase inverter.
Filters the DC current together with L001.
Power module with insulated-gate bipolar transistor (IGBT). Converts the DC voltage from the rectifier back DC power supply to AC voltage.
Filters the AC output and removes distortions together with the CB03.
Galvanic isolation between the load and the DC. Transforms the AC output to the correct value for the load.
Filters the AC output and removes distortions together with the L002. Subdivided into several sections.
Protects each section of CB03. If one section has a failure that section will be isolated.

The static switch consists of antiparallel-switched power thyristors. It is used to automatically transfer the load to bypass without interruption. Can only be transferred if the bypass mains voltage is within tolerance. Transfer can occur when:

li.ph: The system is heavily overload.
The inverter cannot keep the output voltage within tolerance.
The battery is discharged during battery operation.
DC input power is unavailable or out of tolerance.
The system has been switched to static bypass operation from the front panel.

entry.ph: Protects the static switch EN A035.

The static switch EA is an option at the inverter output. It can make the switch over between operating modes more reliable. Especially in redundant systems it can make the switch back to normal operation easier for one system. With EA one unit can keep the inverter running in no-load operation, instead of switching it off. This additional mode is called either Standby+ or Hot standby depending on the redundant configuration. For more information see chapter .

Supplied by the rectifier mains or the bypass mains. Part of the redundant internal power supply together with A202. One of the two supplies can supply the system alone. In case of one of the supplies stops suppling the system an alarm is generated on the front panel.

Supplied from the internal DC bus. Part of the redundant internal power supply together with A201. One of the two supplies can supply the system alone. In case of one of the supplies stops suppling the system an alarm is generated on the front panel.

li.ph: Fan-transformer that transforms the voltage to the correct voltage to the fans.
Fans with internal hall sensor for monitoring the number of revolutions.
Fan monitor that monitors the number of revolutions of each fan. If the number of revolutions falls below the preset value an alarm is generated.

entry.ph: Controls the main parts (rectifier, inverter, static switch(es)) of the system and the alarm relays. Monitors the voltages, the currents and the alarms. Communicates with the front panel, the serial connections and between multiple units in redundant systems.

Contains control fuses and distributes power to auxiliary circuits and different modules. Converts AC and DC voltages to lower standard values for the controller. Secures galvanic isolation for the controller.
The human machine interface (HMI) of the system. Contains a display, operating status indications, alarm indications, operating buttons and numpad. For more information see .

The ISBS controller controls the static switch EN A035 based on the control signal from the controller board A070. It can independently switch the system to independent static bypass (ISBS) operation. The ISBS controller has an independent power supply and independent supervision of the output voltage. It is connected to the two relays K701 and K702.
Used for communication between two units in a redundant system. The board is located in the system parts and the connections are located in the low-voltage section.
Connection interface to the controller board A070.
Indicates the status of the complete ISBS controller. If the relay is activated, the controller is fully operational and ready to react on the control signal from the controller board.
Indicates that the ISBS controller has switched the system to ISBS operation.

Connection terminal for the rectifier mains input. The rectifier mains input requires an external protective device. A fuse or MCCB according to the technical specification. Always L1, L2, L3, and PE.
Rectifier input circuit breaker or switch-disconnector
Breaker for the rectifier mains input. The rectifier mains input requires an external protective device. A fuse or MCCB according to the technical specification.
Galvanic isolation between mains input and rectifier. Transforms the mains input to the correct value for the rectifier.
Converts the AC voltage from the mains to DC voltage.
To create a 12-pulse thyristor rectifier-bridge an additional 6-pulse thyristor rectifier-bridge can be used. This reduces the repercussion of the rectifier back to the mains.
Only optional in single systems. Always used in redundant systems.
Controls the rectifier and the alarm relays. Monitors voltages, currents and alarms. Communicates with the front panel, the serial connections and between multiple units in redundant systems.

Contains control fuses and distributes power to auxiliary circuits and different modules. Converts AC and DC voltages to lower standard values for the controller. Secures galvanic isolation for the controller.
Fans with internal hall sensor for monitoring the number of revolutions. Not needed in systems with low power.
Interface between the fans and the interface board. Controls the fan speed.
Connection terminal for the battery connection. The battery connection requires an external protective device. A fuse or MCCB according to the technical specification.
Can either provide isolation for the load from the rectifier or both the rectifier and the battery. Only optional in single systems. Always used in redundant systems.
Connection terminal for the load (L+) and (L-).
An interface board with status relays and input terminals. For more information see the chapter .

li.ph: Two common alarm relays with a programmable delay between 0-327 seconds (default value is 5 seconds)
A battery operation relay with a 30 seconds delay Indication from the upstream rectifier.
A bypass operation relay (static switch EN active)
Battery temperature sensor
Remote start/stop
Emergency power off (EPO)
Boost charge blocked
Battery breaker status

entry.ph: Used for communication to the smart slot translator and then to the NMC. Contains one serial output (RS-232). For more information see the Network Monitoring System user guide.
16 change-over relays for alarms from the alarm panel. If the alarm is active the relay is in the volt free position. For more information see the chapter .The available relays are:

sl.sli: K004 Battery discharged DC low warning

entry.ph: 16 change-over relays for alarms from the alarm panel, status indications from the mimic diagram and an indication if there are alarms that are not confirmed. If the alarm is active the relay is in the volt free position. For more information see the chapter .The available relays are:

sl.sli: K010 The static switch EN is on
K011 The static switch EA is on
K013 Boost charge is enabled (Not used)
K014 The rectifier is on (Not used)
K016 External horn (indicates that there are alarms that have not been acknowledged)

entry.ph: Interface between the controller and the network management card.
Network management card (NMC) used to monitor measurements, events and alarms locally or remotely. For more information see the chapter or the Network Management System user guide.
An interface board with status relays and input terminals. For more information see the chapter .
